docs.snippet: Peru's leftist-oriented military leaders are vowing to press ahead with their reorganizing of Peruvian life despite increased opposition at home and a growing feeling of international isolation.
docs.lead_paragraph: Peru's leftist-oriented military leaders are vowing to press ahead with their reorganizing of Peruvian life despite increased opposition at home and a growing feeling of international isolation.
docs.abstract: Peruvian Foreign Min Miguel Angel de la Flor Valle says mil leaders plan to press ahead with their reorgn of Peruvian life despite increased opposition at home and growing feeling of internatl isolation, recent int; mil govt, which took power in '68, has sought sweeping econ and soc changes in face of hostility from traditional pol parties; program has not impeded econ growth; Pres Advisory Com head Gen J Graham Hurtado says major problem is convincing people of need for change, int; notes broad lack of understanding of Govt's aims, growing counterrevolutionary offensive and disturbing arms build-up in neighboring Chile and Ecuador; says Peru is buying new arms to counter build-up; Peruvian arms purchases from USSR, US, GB, Italy, Netherlands and W ger noted; internal opposition, crystallized in recent teachers strike, seen as chief danger to mil govt; teachers movement has attracted broad spectrum of people dissatisfied with mil and is led by combination of ultra-leftists and right-wing Amer Popular Revolutionary Alliance; Govt civilian leader C Delgado Olivera holds only alternative to present revolution is reactionary mil junta; cites achievements of his Natl System to support Soc Mobilization; says peasant movement is regime's most important soc base; concedes orgn has failed to win support of pol parties; says even Communist and Christian Dem parties, which nominally support revolution, do not really favor it; farmers assembly and Graham illus (L)

headline.main: Peru's Leaders Vow to Press Reorganization of the Nation's Life; A Contrast With Chile

docs.snippet: Now that the draw to pair the 16 countries into four groups and the first-round schedule for the World Cup have been settled, reaction from the federations and other national soccer authorities involved has been mixed--and predictable.
docs.lead_paragraph: Now that the draw to pair the 16 countries into four groups and the first-round schedule for the World Cup have been settled, reaction from the federations and other national soccer authorities involved has been mixed--and predictable.
docs.abstract: A Yannis analyzes pairings for World Cup soccer champ; illus (M)

headline.main: World Cup Pairings Produce Predictable Reaction

docs.snippet: BANETH: The practical basis is that if we are to have a reasonably orderly world, very poor countries should have some hope that they will become less poor. I am not sure how strong the moral basis for this is, but it has been said that the rich...
docs.lead_paragraph: BANETH: The practical basis is that if we are to have a reasonably orderly world, very poor countries should have some hope that they will become less poor. I am not sure how strong the moral basis for this is, but it has been said that the rich countries should feel some obligation to help.
docs.abstract: IBRD officials Jean Baneth, Dragoslav Avramovic, Attila Karaosmanoglu, Barend A DeVries and Stanley Please discuss food production problems and possibility of food shortages in Far East, Africa and Latin Amer; India and Ghana cited as examples; officials illus (Internatl Econ Survey article) (L)

headline.main: Who Will Feed the World's Hungry?; The Quality of Aid

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES - What may come to be referred to as the second industrial revolution broke out last year, and nowhere else was it so far reaching as in Latin America.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES - What may come to be referred to as the second industrial revolution broke out last year, and nowhere else was it so far reaching as in Latin America.

docs.snippet: Washington officials concerned with Cuban affairs focused attention today primarily on two statements made in Havana last night. One was by Premier Castro expressing approval of improved relations between East and West.
docs.lead_paragraph: Washington officials concerned with Cuban affairs focused attention today primarily on two statements made in Havana last night. One was by Premier Castro expressing approval of improved relations between East and West.
docs.abstract: Washington officials concerned with Cuban affairs are focusing particular attention on Cuban Premier Castro's statement Jan 29 expressing approval of East-West detente and on Brezhnev condemnation of past Communist policy of trying to export revolution; also interested in Castro's implied criticism of China for 'reviling USSR' and 'betraying proletarian internationalism' (M)

byline.original: By DAVID BINDERSpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: In August, 1967, the Organization of Latin-American Solidarity proclaimed in Havana that the only way to overcome imperialism and establish socialism on the continent was through armed struggle. LatinAmerican radical leftists, led by Cuba's Premier...
docs.lead_paragraph: In August, 1967, the Organization of Latin-American Solidarity proclaimed in Havana that the only way to overcome imperialism and establish socialism on the continent was through armed struggle. LatinAmerican radical leftists, led by Cuba's Premier Castro, openly condemned the Soviet Union and the classic Communist parties for their "reformist" tactics.
docs.abstract: article on decided rightward shift in Latin Amer with major setbacks for left describes crushing of Tupamaros as worst defeat for revolutionaries (S)

headline.main: South America Drifts Right, And the Left Goes Along; The State of Latin Radicalism
